Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2013 07:15AM hzzr wrote: I wasn't told how often but twice a day is what I've averaged.  if they are full certainly empty them!  be sure to measure and record what you removed.  I had one drain taken out yesterday so that was 6 days post-op.  The other will be another 4 or 5 days I think (it's on the same side just a slightly different spot).

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2013 11:46PM hzzr wrote: I will chime in here on the emotional/funk thread too.  The last 3 days have been terrible - full of anxiety that has nothing to do with cancer or surgery but I'm sure is fueled by it.  Tears too.  My situation is made more complicated as I'm on my own (no DH) and that is a recent change.  I'm set up for counselling in the new year but what has been helping more than anything is reaching out to others -  to talk about what's going on but usually just to chat and catch up. This thread has been wonderful for knowing I'm not alone.  Bobogirl I hope you are ok - thinking of you and everyone who is recovering or will be having procedures this week.  Hugs to all - we will get through this and there will be brighter days coming very soon!

Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2014 11:12AM hzzr wrote: I did chemo 8 years ago (ACT) and worked through it, taking 2 days off per treatment.  Would I do it again? In that environment, no.  Some people seemed to forget my limitations, despite the fact that everyone knew and that I was wearing a kerchief to hide my hair loss.  I felt that the perception of my performance was impacted.  But the current job I have is very engaging and the team is smaller and more family like, so I would go to work and do as much as I could.  You do have to gauge how work will respond to your limitations.  Not to scare anyone but chemo will have an impact - if nothing else, it will make you tired.  I was lucky not to have nausea but did have chemo brain  and for a while afterwards.  Just survived the worst cold I've had in years with a 102 degree fever and awful headache.  I was doing ok recovery wise until that! Best news is that my last drain just got removed!  Probably the cold had something to do with it drying up as I'm dehydrated despite drinling tons of water.  Don't care - so glad to be free of that thing!!!
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

I'll be thinking of you all as we head into December.   There's far too many of us in any month!

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2013 04:49AM hzzr wrote: Got my results yesterday...residual DCIS in the breast tissue which meant Mx was definitely called for so that puts any question there to rest.  Although I had sentinel nodes done in a previous surgery this year (which were clear), a few nodes attached to some scar tissue came out during the Mx and the pathologist found one wh a micromet.  I've read these are usually ignored but curious if anyone's had one and what doctors told you...

Come February, this will be 1 year since the mammogram that caught the DCIS. So hard to believe it has taken this long. December 9 will come both too fast and not fast enough. So wish I could take my friends into the OR with me! Will be thinking of everyone who is undergoing surgery next week and hoping for an easy time for you all.

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2013 07:44PM hzzr wrote: By the way, I got my path report last week.  I had the SLNB done in July, which came back clear, but apparently a few nodes came out this time along with scar tissue when doing the MX, and so the pathologist checked them.  One had a micromet.  Now I'm waiting to see if the MO or RO want to do anything about it.  I've found studies that show micromets should be considered node-negative, as well as others that show they should be treated as node-positive.  Confused and a bit anxious.  Not even sure the onco will call but at least I have a tamoxifen update appt with him mid-January.  Thought I was now just on the reconstruction side of things!  And perhaps I am, but just don't know that for sure yet.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2013 08:19PM hzzr wrote: I agree with warrior woman - it isn't easy but it is easier than you expect it to be. As for what to take - a small easily digested snack perhaps?  I arrived late from the OR to the hospital floor and so nothing for dinner but then no one ordered breakfast either.  If you are like me, I am hungry when I come out of gen. anesthesia so this was a little crisis!   I know to go slow because your GI tract slows down but I needed something for my blood sugar.  Nurse was kind and rustled up some cheerios at night and the next morning too. Everything else i took was extraneous except my cellphone.  I didn't sleep great first night so was emailing friends and family (mom was so surprised to get an email so quick!  They live far away). I can read and watch stuff on this phone too so it made the night pass much easier.  Had to laugh the next morning tho - surgeon always finds me in his exam rooms playing with my phone (I hate waiting, or rather, I hate idling) and here at 7 am he comes round to check on me and I'm awake and guess what - playing with my phone!  Another patient had been yelling for the nurse which woke me up early.  I'm sure he was like 'what the...?  Does she ever stop using that phone?' :-)
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2013 05:17AM hzzr wrote: Small headphones for the cellphone/smartphone Gum

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2013 04:10AM hzzr wrote: I don't believe we do Oncotype in Canada.   It's never been offered to me.  I wonder if it is available at all?  Their website shows the US and a few other countries but not Canada.  As for the onc team, it could go either way.  If they ever treat micromets then I'm sure they will do so with me, given my history and age.  Truthfully I'm nervous about there being another micromet left in there, silently growing away over the next few years... Guess I will find out in the new year what we're doing.  Til then I won't worry about it but rather sit back and enjoy the holidays!

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2013 07:33PM hzzr wrote: JMMS - I just had the airport experience today and last week.  Flew in Canada.  The outgoing security was nothing - I didn't even ding!  Didn't have to dig out the TE card nor doctor's note which the PS kindly wrote for me.  However, coming home was a bit different - I forgot to take my safety pin off the drain (yes, 3 weeks postop and I STILL have a drain grrrrrr) and of course I 'dinged' this time.  Was going to do the full body scan option but when they saw the drain they told me pat-down was the only option, due to my 'physical abnormality'.  Folks, this was not a good time for me to get emotional...but I nearly lost it as I had fears about what was coming. They were going to take me to a room that was private, but apparently there was a cat in that room (???) so I said just do it right here, right now and get it over with.  I realize now they were trying to be respectful and give me privacy but I was thrown off.  In the end it was nothing - over in a jiffy - but emotionally I was feeling very vulnerable.  I also had trouble getting help from airline staff to put my carry-on in the overhead bin on the trip out, so I checked it when coming home. Neither situation impacted my family visit in the slightest, but I have to say that my fuse is extremely short for 'everyday frustrations'.  That I learned, almost the hard way!  Tears and airport security do not mix <grin>
Posts.Title: December 2013 surgeries bobogirl sandra4611

Posts.Content: hzzr wrote: I recently had my exchange surgery and at the same time had my other breast (left side) reduced. It is now somewhat bigger than it was post surgery and although i saw the PS on Monday it seems a bit bigger to me since then.  One complication is that i had BC on the reduced (left) side 10 years ago and have no lymph nodes on that side.  PS did not put any drains in for this procedure.  i am healing well otherwise and have returned to work 11 days post surgery. Has anyone ese had a similar procedure (with or without lymph nodes on the reduced side) and did the fluid go away onbits own?  I am worried the difference will be permanent if i do nothing. 2005: IDC; Left Lx + rads + ACT chemo + Herceptin + Tamoxifen. 2013: DCIS with microinvasion + micromet (1); Right Lx + re-excision for margins (2x) + right Mx + TE. Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2013 09:55PM hzzr wrote: I don't suffer from vertigo (but can understand your concerns).  I've had a few surgeries now and really like having a warmed blanket when I am coming around.  I'm like you - I want to get up and get going, especially with respect to thinking and being aware.  The blanket seems to settle me down and make me more 'comfy' and relaxed.  It's like a hug :-)
